subject: Fix race when changing node power states (Threads approach) [PROOF OF CONCEPT]
commit_message:
Fix race when changing node power states (Threads approach) [PROOF OF CONCEPT]

This patch implements approach proposed in [1] but uses local
Conductor threads instead of sync/async AMQP calls to acheive
syncronized validation and async changing of the power state.

The main problem with threads is how to release the node lock in
the end of the job. Unlike the patch mentioned above, this one
keeps the same lock during the whole task. It uses expanded
python Thread that provides thread_end_callback functionality. The
end_callback is used to release the lock in the end of the job.
Modifyed thread implemented here probably can be replaced with
concurrent.futures implementation.

Pros and cons comparing to [1]
+ Single lock for the whole task (no need for intent locks)
- Doubling internal ifaces to provide both sync and async ways:
node_power_action, async_node_power_action etc..
- Unable to use WITH block with the async version, a little
mindblowing lock releasing scheme.

NOTE: The unit tests are not implemented yet. If we decide to go
this way I'll polish the solution and create tests.

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/65327/4

subject: Change rsync subprocess to use tempfile
commit_message:
Change rsync subprocess to use tempfile

I'm pretty sure this is what causes a lot of blow ups with the rsync
object-replicator in our larger clusters.

Unfortunately, I don't know of a good way to test for this behavior
other than to ensure existing tests all pass (they do) and then see if
it improves the situation in the real world (to be determined).

Included commentary, in case the link goes away:

> A closer inspection of the subprocess.Popen docs revealed a warning
> "Note: The data read is buffered in memory, so do not use this method
> if the data size is large or unlimited." I'd probably read that before
> and assumed that it was a warning about possibly consuming a lot of
> memory and being inefficient if you try to pass a lot of data around.
> So I ignored it. The STDOUT chatter of shell scripts that I was
> collecting for logging purposes did not strike me as "large" (65K is
> positively tiny these days) and it isn't an application where I'm
> particularly concerned about memory consumption or efficiency.
>
> Apparently, that warning actually means "Note: if there's any chance
> that the data read will be more than a couple pages, this will
> deadlock your code." What was happening was that the memory buffer was
> a fixed size. When it filled up, it simply stopped letting the child
> process write to it. The child would then sit and patiently wait to be
> able to write the rest of its output.
>
> Luckily the solution is fairly simple. Instead of setting stdout and
> stderr to PIPE, they need to be given proper file (or unix pipe)
> objects that will accept a reasonable amount of data. (A further hint
> for anyone who found this page because they encountered the same
> problem and are looking for a fix: Popen() needs real file objects
> with fileno() support so StringIO-type fake file objects won't work;
> [tempfile.TemporaryFile] is your friend).

http://thraxil.org/users/anders/posts/2008/03/13/Subprocess-Hanging-PIPE-is-your-enemy/

Change-Id: I97c71dba3dc35d224c9d05059cc0f41fdb255f1b

subject: Copy hook directories with -r into the chroot
commit_message:
Copy hook directories with -r into the chroot

Copying the hook directories into the chroot with -r allows dependent
elements to easier implement support for the package install type.

For example, nova-api depends on nova. And, only the nova element has a
source-repository file, the nova-api element does not. As such,
source-repositories doesn't know to enable the nova-api package
installation type. This is easily fixed by having the depending elements
such as nova-api break out there source and package installs into
nova-{package|source}-install directories just like the nova element
does. When source-repositories creates the symlinks for the enabled
installation type, all the depending elements that have a
nova-package-install will also be automatically enabled.

The other option would have been to make dependent elements such as
nova-api start using their own source-repository-nova-api file and not
rely on the one from nova, however that presents other issues, such as
reusing git checkouts in source-repositories and accidentally mixing
source and package install types in nova.

Change-Id: Id1e8d3b3a759b9637be2150ee22a0abbe58cf26d

commit_message:
Fix mocking of utcnow() for model datetime cols

Now when we are going to deprecate timeutils.set_time_override()
and use mock instead, it easy to hit the following gotcha: when
testr does tests discovering, it imports all modules within a given
directory and it might happen that common.db.sqlalchemy.models

original timeutils.utcnow() function, which will be called later
when the model will be saved to a DB, if created_at or updated_at
value aren't provided.

subject: Fix Error 400 Header Line Too Long

Fix Error 400 Header Line Too Long

Fix Error 400 Header Line Too Long when using Identity v3 PKI Tokens

Uses swift.conf max_header_size option to set wsgi.MAX_HEADER_LINE,
allowing the operator to customize this parameter.

The default value has been let to 8192 to avoid unexpected

- Auth tokens generated by Keystone v3 API include the catalog.

commit_message:
Use constant-time string compare for /info requests

If you GET /info?swiftinfo_sig=<HMAC>&swiftinfo_expires=<TIME>, then
the response contains any admin-only information that's been
registered (via calls to register_swift_info(admin=True)).

The bad news is that the info controller isn't using streq_const_time
to compare the valid HMAC signatures with the passed-in one, leading
to a possible timing attack.

The good news is that this isn't a security hole since there's
absolutely nothing interesting in the admin-only section yet, so even
if an attacker does suss out a valid signature, they don't learn
anything. However, we should still fix this in case anything
interesting ever does get added.
